results.headline: Review: ‘Tower,’ About 1966, Before Mass Shootings Became Routine
results.summary_short: Keith Maitland’s documentary on the University of Texas tower mass shooting breathes life into victims rather than dissecting the shooter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tower

results.headline: Review: ‘Godzilla’ Returns, Again, With a Wink
results.summary_short: “Shin Godzilla” puts Tokyo in peril. Can the bumbling bureaucrats get their act together in time?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shin Godzilla

results.headline: Review: ‘Middle School,’ Where the Principal Is Mean and the Pranks Messy
results.summary_short: This movie, adapted from a book from James Patterson’s library, follows a protagonist struggling with life in a new school and a nasty administrator.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Middle School

results.headline: Review: In ‘Newtown,’ Understated Eloquence but No Peace
results.summary_short: Kim A. Snyder’s documentary chronicles survivors of a Connecticut school massacre almost four years after one of the worst mass shootings in American history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Newtown

results.headline: Review: In ‘Theo Who Lived,’ a Journalist Tells of His Capture by Al Qaeda
results.summary_short: A documentary follows Theo Padnos as he recreates his kidnapping and detainment by anti-American forces in Syria.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Theo Who Lived

results.headline: Review: In ‘Being 17,’ 2 Boys Teeter Between Animosity and Attraction
results.summary_short: André Téchiné’s film centers on schoolyard combatants whose violent tussles begin to have an undertone of repressed desire.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being 17

results.headline: Review: An Undetonated Missile and Evil Spirits Lurk in ‘Under the Shadow’
results.summary_short: In this horror film, a woman with a husband away on the front is left with her daughter, an unexploded missile and possibly a supernatural visitor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Shadow

results.headline: Review: ‘Voyage of Time,’ the Cosmology of Terrence Malick (the Short Version)
results.summary_short: Brad Pitt narrates a 45-minute Imax version of Mr. Malick’s documentary, a tour of astrophysics, biology, philosophy and religion. A feature-length cut will be released later to conventional theaters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Voyage of Time

results.headline: Review: In ‘Blue Jay,’ Returning to Romantic Roads Not Taken
results.summary_short: In Alex Lehmann’s film, Sarah Paulson and Mark Duplass play high school sweethearts who run into each other two decades later.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blue Jay

results.headline: Review: In ‘Mirzya,’ Echoes of ‘Romeo and Juliet,’ Lushly Shot
results.summary_short: Fine leading performances lift this film, which is based on a Punjab folk tale of star-crossed lovers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirzya

results.headline: Review: In Henry Jaglom’s ‘Ovation,’ the Action Is Backstage
results.summary_short: The setting for this director’s lighthearted 20th feature is a stage production of “The Rainmaker,” whose cast is a hairbreadth from unemployment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ovation

results.headline: Review: ‘37,’ a Fictional Retelling of the Kitty Genovese Story
results.summary_short: This version of the story returns to the popular, but discredited belief that dozens of people deliberately ignored the cries of Ms. Genovese.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 37

results.headline: Review: ‘The Great Gilly Hopkins,’ a Child’s Story Elevated by Grown-Ups
results.summary_short: Although this film centers on an unruly foster child adapting to a new home, the real heart of the movie lies in the performances of Kathy Bates and Glenn Close.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Gilly Hopkins

results.headline: Review: ‘The Late Bloomer,’ About a Sex Therapist Who Missed Puberty
results.summary_short: This comedy, directed by Kevin Pollak, searches somewhat desperately for laughs in the premise of 30-year-olds acting like frat boys.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Late Bloomer

results.headline: Review: Growing Up Fast in ‘London Town’ Amid Punk and Thatcherism
results.summary_short: The music of the Clash is a driving force in this film, and Jonathan Rhys Meyers appears as Joe Strummer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London Town

results.headline: Review: In Nate Parker’s ‘The Birth of a Nation,’ Must-See and Won’t-See Collide
results.summary_short: This film about Nat Turner’s slave rebellion is an ambitious attempt to corral the contradictions of history within the conventions of popular narrative.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Birth of a Nation

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Girl on the Train,’ a Boozy Emily Blunt Never Winks
results.summary_short: In this adaptation of the best-selling mystery by Paula Hawkins, Ms. Blunt is one of three unreliable narrators, a heavy-drinking fantasist at that.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl on the Train

results.headline: Review: ‘Homeland: Iraq Year Zero’ Chronicles a War-Torn Family
results.summary_short: This two-part film from Abbas Fahdel gives a before-and-after account of his relatives’ lives around the time of the 2003 conflict.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Homeland: Iraq Year Zero

results.headline: Review: ‘M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story’ Recalls a Cricketer’s Ascent
results.summary_short: The life of the captain of the winning 2011 World Cup team is recounted in this biopic from Neeraj Pandey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story

results.headline: Review: ‘13TH,’ the Journey From Shackles to Prison Bars
results.summary_short: Ms. DuVernay makes a startling and powerful statement about the prison industrial complex and the history of black lives in post-Jim-Crow America.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 13TH
